duck: Military research facilities of the United Kingdom
The Royal Radar Establishment, or RRE, was a renaming of the Radar Research Establishment following a visit by Queen Elizabeth II in 1957.
The name Royal Radar Establishment was given to the existing Radar Research Establishment following a visit by Queen Elizabeth II in 1957.
20th-century military history of the United Kingdom

cat: 20th-century military history of the United Kingdom
Military research facilities of the United Kingdom
wiki.text:
The name 'Royal Radar Establishment' was given to the existing 'Radar Research
Establishment' following a visit by Queen Elizabeth II in 1957. Both names were
abbreviated to 'RRE'. The establishment had been formed, under its first name,
in 1953 by merging the Telecommunications Research Establishment (TRE) and the
Radar Research and Development Establishment (RRDE). These had worked on
airborne and ground based radar, respectively.<ref name=coldHot>[http://books.g-
oogle.com/books?id=HMx_6FtHBcUC&pg=PA249&dq=w+j+richards+rre&hl=en&ei=0G1YTaT8O-
sSqlAfhu8zDBw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=2&ved=0CCwQ6AEwAQ#v=onepage&-
q=w%20j%20richards%20rre&f=false Robert Bud and Philip Gummett, Cold war, hot
science: applied research in Britain's defence laboratories, NMSI Trading Ltd.
Science Museum, London, 2002.]</ref><ref name=physicsAtRRE>R.A. Smith, Physics
at the Radar Research Establishment, Malvern, Proceedings of the Royal Society
of London. Series A, Mathematical and Physical Sciences Vol. 235, No. 1200 (Apr.
10, 1956), pp. 1-10.</ref> RRE was located in Malvern, Worcestershire, where
both TRE and RRDE had been housed at different sites. The earlier research and
development work of TRE and RRDE on radar, solid state physics, electronics, and
computer hardware and software was continued in the merged establishment, and
the overall scope was extended to include cryogenics and other topics. Infrared
detection for guided missiles and heat sensing devices was a major defence
application.
